hint.workaround: Unroll your loop if trip count is significantly higher than target unroll factor and if some data references are common to consecutive iterations. This can be done manually. Or by recompiling with -funroll-loops and/or -floop-unroll-and-jam. Or with the unroll (resp. unroll_and_jam) directive on top of the inner (resp. surrounding) loop. You can enforce an unroll factor: !GCC$ unroll N

expert.title: Cycles and memory resources usage
expert.txt:
Assuming all data fit into the L1 cache, each iteration of the binary loop takes 2.33 cycles. At this rate:
 - 5% of peak load performance is reached (3.43 out of 64.00 bytes loaded per cycle (GB/s @ 1GHz))
 - 5% of peak store performance is reached (1.71 out of 32.00 bytes stored per cycle (GB/s @ 1GHz))

expert.title: Front-end bottlenecks
expert.txt:
Performance is limited by instruction throughput (loading/decoding program instructions to execution core) (front-end is a bottleneck).

By removing all these bottlenecks, you can lower the cost of an iteration from 2.33 to 1.00 cycles (2.33x speedup).

header: 0% of peak computational performance is used (0.43 out of 48.00 FLOP per cycle (GFLOPS @ 1GHz))

gain.workaround:
- Try to reorganize arrays of structures to structures of arrays
 - Consider to permute loops (see vectorization gain report)
 - To reference allocatable arrays, use "allocatable" instead of "pointer" pointers or qualify them with the "contiguous" attribute (Fortran 2008)
 - For structures, limit to one indirection. For example, use a_b%c instead of a%b%c with a_b set to a%b before this loop
gain.title: Code clean check
gain.txt:
Detected a slowdown caused by scalar integer instructions (typically used for address computation).
By removing them, you can lower the cost of an iteration from 2.33 to 1.17 cycles (2.00x speedup).

gain.workaround:
- Try another compiler or update/tune your current one:
  * recompile with ftree-vectorize (included in O3) to enable loop vectorization and with fassociative-math (included in Ofast or ffast-math) to extend vectorization to FP reductions.
 - Remove inter-iterations dependences from your loop and make it unit-stride:
  * If your arrays have 2 or more dimensions, check whether elements are accessed contiguously and, otherwise, try to permute loops accordingly:
Fortran storage order is column-major: do i do j a(i,j) = b(i,j) (slow, non stride 1) => do i do j a(j,i) = b(i,j) (fast, stride 1)<<image_col_maj>>
  * If your loop streams arrays of structures (AoS), try to use structures of arrays instead (SoA):
do i a(i)%x = b(i)%x (slow, non stride 1) => do i a%x(i) = b%x(i) (fast, stride 1)
gain.details:
All SSE/AVX instructions are used in scalar version (process only one data element in vector registers).
Since your execution units are vector units, only a vectorized loop can use their full power.
gain.title: Vectorization
gain.txt:
Your loop is not vectorized.
8 data elements could be processed at once in vector registers.
<<image_1x32_256>>By vectorizing your loop, you can lower the cost of an iteration from 2.33 to 0.29 cycles (8.00x speedup).

gain.title: Execution units bottlenecks
gain.txt: Found no such bottlenecks but see expert reports for more complex bottlenecks.
